Consent to be Part of a Research Study on Hawaiian Language and Seal of Biliteracy

Title of the Project:  Education-based efforts to mitigate language loss and preserve linguistic diversity: Aim 1

Principal Investigator: Kristin Davin, Ph.D., UNC Charlotte

Co-investigators: 

Dina Yoshimi, Ph.D. University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa

William Wilson, University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo

Alex Dornburg, Ph.D., UNC Charlotte

 

You are invited to participate in a research study conducted by the University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo Hawaiian language program, the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa. Participation in this research study is voluntary. The information provided is to help you decide whether or not to participate. If you have any questions, please ask. 

Important Information You Need to Know


	The purpose of this study to understand the thoughts of various types of people about Hawaiian language revitalization. The information collected will allow us to better understand the processes, stakeholders, and resources necessary to implement a successful Indigenous language medium/immersion program and to award the Seal of Biliteracy to speakers of an Indigenous language like Hawaiian.
	You are being asked to complete a survey about your background relative to the Hawaiian language, your perceptions of Hawaiian medium/immersion schooling, and your perceptions of the Seal of Biliteracy. The survey will take between 5 and 30 minutes to complete, depending on whether you choose to write in additional comments.
	We do not believe that you will experience any risk from participating in this study. 
	You will not beneﬁt personally by participating in this study. What we learn may be beneﬁcial to others, including to future Hawaiian language preservation and education efforts.

Please read this form and ask any questions you may have before you decide whether to participate in this study. If you would like to see the survey questions or interview questions in advance, please inform Dr. Davin or Dr. Yoshimi.

Why are we doing this study?
 The revitalization efforts of Hawaiian are considered by many as a model for successful language revitalization programs, and the results of this investigation will have immediate applicability for the development of other Native peoples’ language revitalization programs across the United States. This study will provide a quantiﬁcation of perceptions of Hawaiian language revitalization efforts.

Why are you being asked to be in this research study.
You are being asked to be in this study because you live in Hawaiʻi, you are 18 years or older, and you have some level of experience with the Hawaiian language.

What will happen if I take part in this study?
If you choose to participate in this study, you will be asked to complete a survey. The survey is electronic will take between five and thirty minutes to complete.

What are the benefits of this study?
You will not beneﬁt directly from being in this study. However, the people of Hawaiʻi may beneﬁt from the results of this study. Additionally, Indigenous language programs across the United States stand to beneﬁt from this study because it will share best practices in Native peoples’ language revitalization efforts.

What risks might I experience?
We do not believe that you will experience any risk from participating in this study. No personally identifiable information will be linked to your responses.

How will my information be protected?
We plan to publish the results of this study and submit a project report to various Hawaiʻi state offices, including curriculum/teacher resource centers like the Hale Kuamoʻo at the University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo in order to further support Hawaiian in educational settings and national recognition of use of Hawaiian language speaker achievements such as the Seal of Biliteracy. 

How will my information be maintained and destroyed? 
The survey is anonymous. You do not have to provide your name or email address on the survey.

After this study is complete, survey data may be shared with other researchers without asking for your consent again or as may be needed as part of publishing our results. There will be no information provided with the survey that could identify you.   



What are my rights if I take part in this study? 

It is up to you to decide to be in this research study. Participating in this study is voluntary. You can stop responding to the survey at any point; if you do not complete the survey, your responses will not be used. You do not have to answer any questions you do not want to answer and you can take a break at any time during the survey or interview.

Your decision to participate in this research, or to withdraw from participating after initially agreeing, will not impact your grades, academic standing, employment, or your interactions with school teachers or staff.

Who can answer my questions about this study and my rights as a participant?

For questions about this research, you may contact Dr. Kristin Davin at kdavin@uncc.edu or Dr. Dina Yoshimi at dinar@hawaii.edu.
If you have questions about your rights as a research participant, or wish to obtain information, ask questions, or discuss any concerns about this study with someone other than the researcher(s), please contact the Office of Research Protections and Integrity at uncc-irb@uncc.edu or 704-687-1871.
